title: The junior tennis champ who beat Sinner and an AFL star to win $1m
text:
In the space of just a couple of points, Jordan Smith went from a relative unknown to a champion on centre court at a grand slam.

The 1 Point Slam during the Australian Open pitted an array of folks against one another, from tennis legends to random Australian celebrities.

Smith ran the gamut on his way to the $1 million prize on Rod Laver Arena on Wednesday night.

"It has not sunk in, waking up to just an unbelievable feeling," he told ABC News Breakfast.

Loading...

"Overwhelmed and amazed, just so surreal. It was just amazing to be on court last night."

In a field of 48, Smith started his namesake, Geelong AFL star Bailey Smith, who missed a forehand return. Then came a brilliant rally with women's world number 86 Laura Pigossi, with Smith chancing his arm and coming up trumps when Pigossi's backhand volley sailed long.

That sent the 29-year-old into a nerve-wracking match-up with two-time defending champion Jannik Sinner.

Asked if he had any advice for his outmatched opponent, Sinner joked: "Maybe he doesn't need advice if I double fault", although Smith said he did seek some advice from the pros on the sideline.

Tennis battler beats the pros to take home $1 million jackpot Sydneysider Jordan Smith has beaten grand slam champion Jannik Sinner and dual grand slam finalist Amanda Anasimova to take home the prize in the novelty format.

"They're very friendly and very down to earth," he said.

"They helped me out. I asked a few of them for advice and it was pretty cool to just be around them and enjoy it."

But no advice was required as the Italian superstar hit the net cord with his one and only serve to end the match-up before it truly began, with world number one Carlos Alcaraz courtside to mock Sinner's tight attempt.

Next up was the runner-up from the last two women's grand slam singles finals, world number four Amanda Anisimiova, who didn't get her forehand return back into play after a taxing point to take down Daniil Medvedev.

Men's world number 71 Pedro Martinez, fresh off lifting the trophy at the Bengaluru Challenger event in India earlier this month, was next and sprayed a backhand long after a tentative rally, sending Smith into the final.

On the other side of the draw, women's world number 117 Joanna Garland had rolled past men's major runner-ups Nick Kyrgios and Alex Zverev, plus Olympic silver medallist Donna Vekić, en route to the decider.

Garland, who just won the WTA Canberra International last week, said the prize money could help fund her on the tour for a couple of years

She chose to serve but sent her next backhand wide, handing the cash to Smith.

Loading Instagram content

Smith was speechless on court immediately after the fact, but did say he planned to use the money to buy a house with his partner Jess, who was up in the stands at Melbourne Park.

She was sitting alongside Smith's parents, Neil and Michelle, who started Smith's love affair with tennis when he was just three.

Jordan Smith won the NSW qualifiers for the 1 Point Slam last month. (Supplied: Tennis NSW)

For more than 30 years they have run the Castle Hill Tennis Academy in Sydney's north-west.

Neil coached Jordan, the youngest of the three, when he won five national junior titles (two singles and three doubles) from 2008 to 2012 before spending a year on the US college scene at Gonzaga on an athletic scholarship in 2015-16.

Homesickness, COVID and the financial difficulties of being a lower-ranked player on tour — Smith reached a career-high singles ranking of 1,141 in 2023 — led him back to Castle Hill to coach alongside his dad and brothers Blake and Cameron.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Smith made it through last month's qualifiers at the North Shore Open to be crowned the NSW state champion.

Smith said his whole family was stunned he made it through the high-pressure tournament. And so was he.

"I tried to keep it pretty level the whole time, just smile," he said.

"I was going into it thinking I was gonna win one point and it just kept happening and kept getting the points.

"[I was] just trying to smile as much as I can and just enjoy the moment."

title: Fire leaves Harcourt family searching for home in tight rental market
text:
Four weeks after moving to Harcourt with her husband Nick and their three young children, Gladys Goasguen Giugni has lost almost everything.

The family say they are now left with only their passports and the clothes they were wearing when fire swept through the central Victorian hamlet last Friday.

"We're tired," Mr Guigni said.

"We were tired packing up the house, we were tired unpacking.

"We were ready to settle down and had just finished the last box."

Gladys Goasguen Giugni and Nick Giugni, and their three children, ran from their Harcourt home as it caught fire. (Supplied: Gladys Goasguen Giugni and Nick Giugni)

The family ran from their home as it burned around them after being told it was too late to leave Harcourt.

"The fire was all around the house. The pergola collapsed, and the windows exploded," Ms Goasguen Giugni said.

"All the smoke from the plastic and from the metal came in. So then I shut the door, and I told the kids, 'Look, we're going to have to go'.

"As we left the house, a big helicopter launched a water bomb on the house. That created a lot of smoke and toxic fumes, so we just escaped."

The family was renting the home, and have since been vying for a new home in an already tight market.

Vacancy less than 1 per cent

The vacancy rate across the Heathcote, Kyneton and Castlemaine statistical area is just 0.69 per cent, according to PropTrack.

Online records show there are 16 homes available to rent in Castlemaine and the surrounding towns.

Narelle Waller says the bushfires will put more pressure on an already tight rental market. (Supplied: Narelle Waller)

Castlemaine real estate agent Narelle Waller said two of the rentals they managed were destroyed in the fire.

"It's a very tight rental market; it has been tight for a good 18 months to two years," she said.

"We've had a lot of landlords that have sold off their investment properties over that period of time.

" It is going to be quite difficult to be able to find another 40-plus homes for people in our area. "

In total, seven rentals were destroyed in the fire, and six landlords lost their own homes.

Two of those home owners lost both their own home and their rental in the fire.

Ms Waller said that although some houses may not have been destroyed, they may be uninhabitable.

"It is going to put a fair bit of pressure on already a limited market in a small community, but we are reaching out to home owners that might have a vacant property or possibly have had a house sitting on the market that may not be," she said.

Community hope

Ms Waller said property agents had begun contacting other agencies to search for available rentals.

Across central Victoria, residents have opened their homes to people displaced by the weekend's fire, which destroyed 47 houses in Harcourt.

Outside the Victorian Miniature Railway, whiteboards and a cardboard sign listed people needing help and those willing to offer it.

Multiple people have listed rooms and studios on community noticeboards, and others are offering houses they have for sale as short-term accommodation.

Some told the ABC they have had families move into those properties this week.

Rod Printz says insurers need to be proactive in accommodating Victorians displaced in the January bushfires. (ABC News: Matthew Holmes)

Rod Printz, who runs Castlemaine Boutique Accommodation, has 16 bed and breakfast units available for short-term rental, but is considering renting them out long-term at a cheaper rate.

"We can accommodate up to 140 guests, and we can move people around to accommodate fire people," he said.

" The short term's a hard thing to throw people in immediately, but for the long term, we could put people in for 12 months. "

Mr Printz said it was important for families to stay close to Harcourt so they could continue with work and school commitments while they rebuilt.

The Giugni family would love a home just like their Harcourt one.

"We know this is where we want to live. We had a great property in Harcourt, with trees everywhere, it was a dream," Mr Giugni said.

"We were living in the south of France once upon a time, and it brought back some of those feelings and the people were nice."

title: Fans 'disappointed and annoyed' by Aus Open's Opening Week marketing
text:
The first week of the Australian Open has seen record crowds across the opening three days, but some fans have been left frustrated by the "confusing" marketing, saying they did not realise the opening week of the tournament was not the first week of the main draw.

The opening day of tennis saw 29,261 people pass through the gates as qualifiers kicked off on Monday, almost four times the previous record of 7,543, from last year.

Continuing the trend, the second day's attendance was 34,209 and the third day was 36,973 — both beating the second and third day records from 2025.

Loading...

Previously it was free to attend qualifying matches, but that changed in 2024. Now, ground passes are $20 with children able to attend events in what is being marketed as Opening Week for free.

Tennis Australia (TA) chief executive Craig Tiley said he was thrilled with the turnout.

"It doesn't feel like it's the first day of qualifiers, it feels in many ways like it's the first day of the event," Tiley said on Monday.

"But this is the first day of 21 days of activity, entertainment, sport."

But one source who works at the Australian Open in events told the ABC — speaking on the condition of anonymity — that they had seen significant complaints from people not realising the main draw did not start until Sunday.

Many fans got to see top players in action during exhibition matches and practice sessions during opening week of the Australian Open. (Getty: Andy Cheung)

The source said lots of people, including first timers to the event and families, have been left confused and frustrated after assuming "Opening Week" meant week one of the main tournament and not qualifiers.

Kylie Gualano is one such fan, who said she purchased 10 day-pass tickets via the Ticketmaster app across Tuesday, Thursday and Friday for herself, her kids and in-laws.

"There was no indication to suggest it was qualifying and advertising had said that was the Opening Week, so I didn't think twice — although I didn't think about dates, just chose the first available tickets," Gualano told the ABC.

"It wasn't until Monday night that we realised that other tournaments were on [in Adelaide, Kooyong and Hobart], so we tried to Google it.

"When you Google 'When does the Aus Open start?' it says from the 12th of Jan, so it took a while to figure it out."

TA told the ABC: "Qualifying has been a key part of the ticketing promotion" for Opening Week.

The Australian Open website page dedicated to Opening Week. (Supplied)

"This is the third year of AO Opening week, and we've implemented an extensive awareness campaign to build excitement around the qualifying tournament," TA said.

But Gualano shared the imagery of those ground passes below, which feature images of defending champions Jannik Sinner and Madison Keys, as well as top seeds like Aryna Sabalenka, Carlos Alcaraz and Coco Gauff.

Ground passes for the Australian Open opening week. (Supplied.)

Nowhere does it say the matches on those days are "qualifiers".

The Opening Week features charity exhibitions matches, with top players or noteworthy public figures, music performances including Hot Chip and The Presets, practice matches between players and activities for kids.

"I was disappointed and annoyed initially as we had purchased for other people and they were looking forward to it," Gualano said.

"But my [16-year-old] son went yesterday and had a good time. There was food and other activations available.

"But it was a big crowd and difficult to get seats on some courts, which is crazy for qualifying."

TA says it wants all fans to "feel informed and … we are always open to feedback".

title: 'Heartbroken' farm workers chase $260,000 in unpaid wages
text:
Baca artikelnya dalam Bahasa Indonesia

Two years after they worked long hours picking salad vegetables destined for the Christmas tables of Australians, Tommy and Susilo still have not been paid.

"We worked hard, under the hot sun," Tommy, whose name has been changed to protect his privacy, told the ABC.

He said he was "heartbroken and tired".

" Worked long and didn't get paid … very hard, very very upset, but what can I do? "

His colleague, Susilo, said he did more than 100 hours of work in the 2023 pre-Christmas rush.

He said he still had not been paid and the memory was painful.

Experts say the farm industry leaves migrant workers vulnerable to exploitation. (ABC News: Stephanie Anderson)

" Rain, heat — I have family here, a small child and wife, parents at home — of course, it hurts. "

Tommy and Susilo are among a group of at least 20 workers who, according to documents filed by liquidators in court proceedings, are owed a total of more than $260,000.

Tommy hopes that the wages he has not received for the past two years can be paid soon. (ABC News)

The wages are owed for the work they did on Corrigan's Farm in south-east Melbourne, where lettuces, kale and other salad vegetables are grown for customers, including supermarket giants Coles and Woolworths.

The workers were employed by a labour hire group run by Cambodian-born Melbourne man Bunchhay San, who is at the centre of an investigation into a network of labour hire companies accused of tax fraud.

Investigators believe about $60 million from the nine companies has been spirited into the black economy.

Cambodian-born Bunchhay San heads up BCS Green Corp in Melbourne. (Facebook)

A court has heard — in corporate liquidation proceedings concerning entities in the group — allegations of cash being handed over to a mysterious but fear-inspiring figure in the Khmer community, as well as an admission from Mr San that he lied to the Victorian labour hire regulator in order to get an operating license.

The labour hire group operated in an industry that experts say still leaves migrant workers — especially those on visas that restrict their work rights — vulnerable to exploitation, despite efforts by governments and unions to clean it up.

The areas around Melbourne are especially bad, according to the Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO).

A report last June found that of 23 labour hire firms inspected during a regulatory blitz, none complied with workplace law.

Tommy and Susilo said their efforts to get paid — which included complaining to the FWO, the union and even the police — had so far come to nothing.

'Just keep working, don't worry about the money'

Corrigan's Farm, in Casey, on Melbourne's far south-eastern fringe, is run by the Corrigan siblings, Deborah and Darren.

Deborah Corrigan is the co-owner of Corrigan's Farm. (ABC News: Jess Davis)

It is Australia's largest producer of fashionable green kale — they grow three types — but also cultivates salad vegetables and greens, including baby cos lettuce, celery and celeriac.

Suburbia is fast eating up the land around the farm as market gardeners sell out to property developers, and soon Corrigan's will suffer the same fate.

The land, which has been sold to former AFL player Fraser Brown, is to be turned into suburban streets in stages.

But in December 2023, the farm was in full swing.

The workers who say they were unpaid picked vegetables for major supermarket chains, among others. (ABC)

Records of time worked filed with the Federal Court, as part of the investigation into the labour hire group, show that — between December 4 and December 20 — the team Tommy and Susilo were part of worked up to 69 hours a week.

The records were attached to an email from the FWO to their employer, Mr San's company BCS Green Corp.

In the email, FWO inspector Alison Read said the workers should have been paid $28.26 an hour, before tax.

Tommy and Susilo have told the ABC that they were paid for up to 20 hours a week by bank transfer, with the rest handed over in cash.

But, in early December, they allege payment stopped. Susilo provided the ABC with an internet banking statement showing his last wages transfer came from a different company in the labour hire ring group on December 8.

Rise in wage theft complaints From higher education to fast food, Legal Aid says wage theft is "everywhere" in Australia.

Susilo said the group kept working because they were assured by a superior that they would be paid.

"He said, 'Just keep working. Don't worry about the money. I'll keep it. I'll pay you later,' he promised."

Susilo estimates he is personally owed more than 100 hours. He says many in his group (17 or 18 people within a larger cohort of 50–60 workers) are owed similarly, with bank transfers capped at 18–20 hours and the rest in cash at $25 per hour.

Tommy and Susilo said the workers complained to the FWO, which sent officers to the farm.

But they said the FWO officials did not speak to any of the workers in their team who were not getting paid.

"Usually, Fair Work meets people randomly," Tommy said.

Dicky Bill salad farm $10m debt blow Administrators for failed Australian salad farm company Dicky Bill reveal its business debts to hundreds of staff and suppliers could exceed $10 million. Deborah Corrigan said Corrigan's fully cooperated with the FWO investigation and said that she did not know the workers still had not been paid until the ABC told her.

"We paid what we owed to the labour hire providers and, in one instance, paid a third-party liquidator," she said.

The Federal Court documents confirm that the FWO investigated BCS Green Corp, but the outcome of the probe is unknown. The FWO declined to comment.

Susilo also complained to his union, the United Workers Union (UWU). He said the union referred him to a lawyer, who told him he could not help and sent him back to the union.

"They couldn't handle our case," he said.

The union declined to comment on Susilo's case.

But it is not the first time the UWU has had problems at Corrigan's.

Company issued licence despite damning allegations

Documents obtained by the ABC show that in 2020, the union wrote to the Victorian Labour Hire Authority (LHA) objecting to the grant of an operating license to another labour hire firm operating at Corrigan's.

Some of the allegations it made are similar to the ones made by Tommy and Susilo.

The UWU claimed that workers were getting cash in hand for their labour above a cap of 20 to 30 hours a week, and that no super or tax was deducted from their pay.

However, the LHA gave the company a licence.

Australia's fruit and vegetable industry often relies on migrant workers during busy periods. (ABC Wide Bay: Johanna Marie)

Ms Corrigan did not answer detailed questions about this company or BCS Green Corp.

"We only partner with suppliers that are licensed, ethical, and compliant with industrial laws and where our expectations are clearly contained in commercial terms," she said.

"In relation to your story, we previously engaged a labour hire provider whose performance was ultimately unsatisfactory.

"Following our internal compliance and due diligence processes, we ceased engagement with the agency and fully cooperated with Fair Work and the Labour Hire Authority."

Both Coles and Woolworths told the ABC they took human rights seriously and had mechanisms that allowed workers anywhere in their supply chains to raise concerns.

Key takeaways from the ACCC's supermarkets report Allegations of price gouging by the supermarket giants prompted an inquiry into the sector by the ACCC — but after a year of investigating, its final report hasn't been able to say whether it's taking place. Coles said it was investigating after the ABC told it about the non-payment allegations at Corrigan's.

Woolworths said it was told Corrigan's paid the money owed to the workers.

"However, we will be looking into this matter further," a spokesperson said.

" We are deeply concerned about any situation in which a worker has not been paid for the work they've completed. "

Woolworths wants "a national labour hire licensing scheme to provide oversight of these agencies in the horticulture sector and hold them to a higher standard," the spokesperson said.

The LHA cancelled BCS Green Corp's licence in March 2024. It declined to comment.

Woolworths and Coles say they have mechanisms in place that allow farm workers to raise concerns. (ABC News)

'Systematic fraud' meant loss of 'tens of millions'

Liquidator Innis Cull, of PKF, is investigating BCS Green Crop and eight other labour hire companies.

Innis Cull says records show that nine companies withdrew a total of $64m in cash. (Supplied)

In a report to creditors of another company in the group, 1998 KH Crop, he said a total of $64 million in cash had been withdrawn from bank accounts held in the names of the nine companies.

He said the director of 1998 KH Crop, a woman named Chanthy Khut, "is unlikely to have been the real controlling mind of the company".

"I believe that she was a 'dummy director', who was installed as a director to hide the identity of the real controlling parties," he said.

"The company is only one of a series of labour hire companies used primarily by members of the Victorian Cambodian community in the Victorian fruit-picking industry to defraud the Australian Taxation Office.

Cherry picker exploitation Seasonal workers on a major orchard in NSW complain to the Fair Work Ombudsman about working conditions and failure to pay an end-of-season bonus. "The fraud is systemic and organised and has resulted in the loss of many tens of millions (and likely hundreds of millions) of dollars of lost tax revenue.

" I intend on referring this matter to the Australian Federal Police for further investigation of potential criminal conduct. "

He said labour hire licenses were fraudulently obtained from the LHA.

Once up and running, the companies reaped millions of dollars in revenue "in a matter of months", he said.

"The dummy directors were given instructions on cash withdrawals of significant sums — generally between $20,000 to $50,000 of cash was withdrawn from major banks at a time.

"The cash was likely to have been passed to more senior members of the organisation for unknown purposes."

Mr Cull declined to comment specifically on the companies under investigation.

But, speaking generally, he told the ABC he did not believe the large cash withdrawals were used to pay workers.

"We believe that the money has disappeared into the black economy and it's unlikely that we'll ever be able to find out, actually, where that money has gone," he said.

"There are no workers' records, there's no records of who the workers were, how much they were paid, how much should have been retained for tax, etc. etc."

Fear of 'consequences' in Khmer community

Ms Khut, the director of 1998 KH Crop and Mr San, the director of BCS Green Corp, did not respond to the ABC's detailed questions.

But as part of Mr Cull's investigation, both have answered questions while under oath in the Federal Court.

Chanthy Khut refused to answer some questions in the Federal Court due to fear of reprisals in Australia's Khmer community. (Supplied: Instagram)

In November, Ms Khut told the court she previously worked for 1998 KH Crop but refused to say who gave her the job.

The court heard that between May and December 2023, she withdrew $5.7 million in cash from the company's six bank accounts.

Asked about a large cash withdrawal of $25,000, she said it was used to pay farm workers.

Cambodian government arrests more than 1,000 people in cybercrime raids A crackdown by Cambodian authorities on cybercrime has led to more than 1,000 arrests.

But she said she had no records of any payments and did not remember the names of any of the company's 70 employees.

And she admitted she did not pay the workers directly. Instead, she had given the money to a person she described as "the driver" to pass on.

She repeatedly refused to name this person, even after registrar Tim Luxton directly ordered her to.

Asked why not, she said: "My reason is because I am a Khmer person and in Khmer community there will be consequences that I and my family will be going through … our safety is our reason not to be answering that".

" I don't know what kind of person that driver is, and if I expose that person's name, there will be consequences that my family will experience. "

Appearing before the court in January, Mr San said that all of $7.8 million that he withdrew in cash from BCS Green Corp's accounts between May and December 2023 "was paid to the worker".

He admitted to lying to the LHA on an application form for a labour hire licence by saying the company did not pay workers in cash.

"If you say yes, you wouldn't get the licence," he told the court.

Half of Victoria's vegetables are grown around Melbourne's fringes. (ABC News: Jess Davis)

Mr San was questioned in detail about June 14, 2023, when he went to the Chadstone branch of the CBA and withdrew $90,000 and the CBD branch of Suncorp and withdrew an additional $25,000.

Asked what happened to the $115,000, he said he drove to multiple farms around Melbourne and distributed the money to workers.

Asked if he kept any of the millions he withdrew for himself, he said there was never any change.

"No … I don't even see that money, I pay to the workers straight away," he told the court.

'Vulnerable' workers preyed upon, experts say

Legal scholar Laurie Berg, an associate professor of law at the University of Technology Sydney (UTS), said the experiences of Tommy and Susilo echo a broader pattern: underpayment cases in complex food processing supply chains where migrant workers at the bottom have little leverage over the entities at the top.

The FWO's recent survey of farm labour hire found non-compliance was rife across Australia.

Laurie Berg says some migrant workers are in a "precarious situation" as they fear "being sent home". (ABC News: John Gunn)

But the worst areas — earning an "extreme" non-compliance rating with 83 per cent of farms and labour hire companies failing to obey the law — were the Mornington Peninsula and Yarra Valley in Victoria.

"These are some of the most vulnerable workers in Australia," Dr Berg told the ABC.

"They're on short‑term visas in a precarious situation … fearful of being detected by authorities and of being sent home."

Dr Berg argued Australia needed stronger accessorial liability so workers could pursue claims "up the chain" against entities capable of making good, national labour‑hire licensing, streamlined wage recovery, and an expanded Workplace Justice Visa pilot so exploited workers could safely come forward.

Workplace Justice Visa requirements Migrant worker experts say the federal government needs to expand the number of community organisations accredited to process Workplace Justice Visa claims to reduce pressure on existing providers.

Dr Berg said labour‑hire arrangements and remote supply‑chain relationships had made oversight difficult and accountability scarce.

She also called for national, harmonised labour‑hire licensing and streamlined wage recovery mechanisms because "the legal system really doesn't work for workers in cases like this".

"We need stronger accessorial liability laws that would enable a worker to go up the chain to make their claim.

"We need stronger labour‑hire licensing and stronger visa protections," she said.

The UWU's executive director of farms, Caterina Cinanni, also said the Workplace Justice Visa scheme needed to be expanded to cover workers on bridging visas and undocumented workers "because they are facing the greatest risk of exploitation".

She also argued the Fair Entitlements Guarantee, a scheme that pays entitlements to Australian workers when their employer goes bust, should be extended to cover non-residents.

Laurie Berg says it is hard for farm workers to hold people to account for underpayment. (ABC News: Claudia Jambor)

"Cash contracting and the exploitation of temporary migrant workers can only be stopped when all workers, regardless of their visa status, are afforded equal protections by our industrial and visa system," she said.

" Workplace exploitation will remain rife when workers are forced to live in secrecy and are too afraid to share all the information about what is happening to them at work. "

'Even the union couldn't help us'

Susilo and Tommy decided to speak up, despite the risks.

"I've wanted to for a long time, but to whom?" Susilo said.

"We didn't know whom to complain here. Even organisations like the union couldn't help us.

"The problem is, most of us still work there. And they seem — not exactly willing — but they feel like, 'Oh well, let's just keep working and leave that issue.'"

In the meantime, the workers have still been waiting to be paid for the work they did putting greens on Christmas tables.

title: Artwork made more than 70 years ago rediscovered hidden in museum
text:
An Indigenous artwork which was made more than 70 years ago has been re-discovered after decades in a trunk at a museum in regional Western Australia.

It was drawn in 1947 by 12-year-old Claude Kelly, who was part of Australia's Stolen Generation, at Carrolup Native Mission School near the town of Katanning, south of Perth.

The museum that the artwork was found in is about 200 kilometres away from the Carrolup mission.

The painting was found in a trunk at the Corrigin Historical Society. (Supplied)

Corrigin Historical Society curator Steve Brown-Smith said the artwork was donated to them about 25 years ago.

"The curator at the time of the donation died a few years ago so any knowledge that she may have had has gone with her," he said.

"We never displayed the picture, and it has sat, undisturbed, in an old trunk for most of the last 25 years or so."

Hundreds of pieces of artwork from Carrolup have ended up thousands of kilometres away from where they were created.

English woman Florence Rutter visited Australia in 1949 and was given hundreds of Carrolup pieces to exhibit and sell in London.

American Herbert Mayer held a private collection of 127 pieces which he donated to his school, Colgate University in New York, where they remained in storage until 2004 when they were found by chance.

The collection was returned to country in 2013 and given to the John Curtin Gallery in Perth.

Artwork through the lens of children

Claude Kelly's artwork is now being cared for at John Curtin Gallery.

The gallery's senior Carrolup adviser Patricia Ryder said the newly uncovered piece was important for a multitude of reasons, including for families of the artists.

"This could be some tangible evidence of their family connections that they may not have any more info on," she said.

"The Carrolup artworks talk to a time in history that we are really removed from, and it's important to look at the artworks through what those children would have experienced at the time, not from where we are now."

The Herbert Mayer collection of Carrolup artwork is at the John Curtin Gallery. (Supplied: Craig Mengham)

Carrolup collections officer Lisa Liebetrau said the artworks could be very fragile with paper conservators assisting to restore damaged pieces.

"The works being made after the Second World War and also on a mission school where the government and the education department were not providing materials of good quality, so the works were made with whatever was available," she said.

"The new acquisitions that we get in, especially the Claude Kelly that we're talking about, that one had a lot of insect damage, it had a lot debris and dust and things like that," Ms Liebetrau said.

Search continues

The search for the artworks that were created at Carrolup is ongoing.

"We only know 17 of the artists that have been attributed to their pieces, and with 127 artworks in the Herbert Mayer collection you can see why it's important that we continue to push for the research and education aspect so we can try and fill those gaps," Ms Ryder said.

Lisa Liebetrau says the art in the Carrolup collection can be incredibly fragile. (Supplied: Brad Coleman)

In 2022, an exhibition of Carrolup artwork was held in various parts of the United Kingdom to try and find more artwork that could be hanging in homes and galleries over there.

"Although our hopes would be to have them all back, the reality is, this may not be possible," Ms Ryder said.

"Our goal is to attribute more artists or more families of the artist to these artwork."

title: Adelaide Festival Corporation apologises to author Randa Abdel-Fattah
text:
The Adelaide Festival Corporation, which oversees Adelaide Writers' Week, has apologised to Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah and says she will be invited to speak at its next event in 2027.

This year's Writers' Week was cancelled after more than 180 authors and participants withdrew from the event.

That followed a decision to cancel an invitation to Abdel-Fattah, over her commentary about Israel and Zionism.

After a new Adelaide Festival board was installed earlier this week, the corporation said it had reversed its previous decision to exclude Abdel-Fattah and retracted its previous statement.

"We apologise to Dr Abdel-Fattah unreservedly for the harm the Adelaide Festival Corporation has caused her," it said.

Adelaide Writers' Week was cancelled earlier this week. (ABC News)

"Intellectual and artistic freedom is a powerful human right.

"Our goal is to uphold it, and in this instance Adelaide Festival Corporation fell well short."

In a post on social media, Abdel-Fattah said she accepted the apology and would consider the board's invitation to participate in the 2027 festival "at the appropriate time but would be there in a heartbeat if Louise Adler was the director again".

She also said while the statement "acknowledges the harm done, it is not a quick fix to repair the damage and injury inflicted".

Judy Potter was appointed chair of the Adelaide Festival board earlier this week. (ABC News)

In a further statement, new Adelaide Festival Board chair Judy Potter said it also wished to apologise to Louise Adler "that the incredible Adelaide Writers' Week program she had worked so hard to curate for 2026 has been cancelled as a result of the events that have unfolded over the last week after the announcement of the decision to rescind the invitation to Dr Abdel-Fattah".

"We acknowledge the principled stand she took in the extremely difficult decision to resign from her role as Director," she said.

" Louise is a revered figure of Australian literature who we hold in the highest regard. "

Ms Potter also advised that a previous decision to establish a subcommittee of the board to review Adelaide Writers' Week operational decisions had also been rescinded.

Louise Adler resigned as the director of Adelaide Writers' Week earlier this week. (Supplied: Adelaide Festival)

Writers' Week 'will rise again', says board chair

Ms Potter said the board was determined that Writers' Week "will rise again and our energies will be directed to that mission".

"We understand that many in the community are urging reconsideration of the cancellation of Adelaide Writers' Week in 2026," she said.

"While we fervently share that desire, our informed assessment of the situation is that it is simply no longer viable for it to proceed."

Julian Hobba says the Festival team is "grateful for the patience of many Festival artists who have been deeply concerned by the events of the last week". (Supplied)

Adelaide Festival chief executive, Julian Hobba, said the team and new board were now "fully focused on and committed to the successful presentation of Adelaide Festival 2026".

He also said they "acknowledge and are grateful" that Premier Peter Malinauskas and Arts Minister Andrea Michaels had "taken swift action to appoint a new board enabling us to rapidly re-set".

"We also appreciate the Premier's consistent position that the curatorial choices of Adelaide Festival, including Adelaide Writers' Week, are at the discretion of the organisation," he said.

title: Why Alice Springs has become one of Australia's most prolific literary towns
text:
Alice Springs has long captured the imagination of writers seeking solitude, inspiration and a deeper connection to the Australian landscape.

From Nevil Shute's A Town Like Alice to Bruce Chatwin's The Songlines, the central Australian town has served as a literary backdrop for outsiders drawn to the romance and mystery of the desert.

But today, the stories emerging from Alice Springs are increasingly being written by locals — many of them Aboriginal — who are reshaping how Central Australia is represented on the page.

Indigenous stories, in particular, are increasingly being told by Aboriginal authors themselves, across literature as well as art, music and performance.

"A Town Like Alice and Songlines are both classics and still selling strong, but there are now more books being published, particularly by First Nations authors, telling their own stories of growing up and living on Arrernte country," said Bronwyn Druce, manager of Red Kangaroo Books in Alice Springs.

A world-first blak love anthology is coming — and it's about joy An anthology of love stories written by First Nations people is in the works with stories of blak love, joy, and connection capitalising on the fastest growing literary genre in the world.

Red Kangaroo Books, named Australian Bookseller of the Year in 2023, is the only brick-and-mortar bookshop within a 1,500-kilometre radius — and it plays a central role in supporting local writers.

Author Tanya Heaslip, whose memoir An Alice Girl became a bestseller, says the town now has one of the highest concentrations of writers anywhere in the world.

"Alice Springs has more authors per head of population than almost anywhere else — except perhaps Iceland," she said.

According to Heaslip, this shift marks a move away from what she describes as earlier "whitefella literature", which often framed the region through an outsider's lens.

"Central Australia was sometimes portrayed as mysterious or unknowable," she said.

"But now we're seeing stories grounded in lived experience — stories that come from the land and the people who belong to it," said Heaslip.

The desert, she argues, continues to exert a powerful creative pull, but the narratives have evolved. Writers in the Red Centre produce poetry, fiction and non-fiction that is deeply connected to place, culture and community.

She grew up on a remote station and learned to write by listening to the School of the Air. After a career as a lawyer, she returned to her roots.

There are other reasons authors move here, including convenience, but also the beautiful surroundings.

"Shorter commutes to work and back home, the wonderful desert landscape, and a slower pace of life, community, give creatives time and space to work on their craft," Ms Druce said.

"Many people have lived here at some point and had books published. Some more well-known authors that have spent time and lived in Central Australia are Alexis Wright, Robyn Davidson, Jennifer Mills, Kim Mahood, and Nicholas Rothwell," she said.

The best books of 2025 An exciting Australian debut, a bevvy of award-winning literary fiction and more than one heart-wrenching memoir are among our critics' favourite reads of the year.

That shift has been supported by strong local infrastructure. Central Australia is home to its own Indigenous publishing house, alongside an active Northern Territory Writers Centre, which regularly hosts readings and storytelling events — often outdoors, under the stars.

"I can only separate non-fiction and fiction. In the kids' top 10, eight books are by First Nations authors and local," Ms Druce said.

That local focus sets Alice Springs apart from other literary hubs, where writers are often drawn to urban settings or darker genres. While crime fiction dominates markets in parts of Europe, Heaslip says writing from Central Australia tends to be shaped more by geography than by genre.

"There are stories from here about those things too, but mostly our writing is about country," Heaslip said.

The isolation of the region is part of its appeal. Alice Springs sits thousands of kilometres from Australia's major cities, in a landscape once covered by an inland sea and shaped over millions of years.

It is also a place steeped in Arrernte culture and surrounded by other ancient Aboriginal traditions, and it is convenient for authors.

What's Australia's favourite book of this century? We've crunched the numbers behind the Top 100 Books countdown.

For Heaslip, that combination of remoteness, history and community continues to inspire.

"I love Central Australia with all my heart," she said, "Its powerful MacDonnell Ranges, hidden valleys, crystal-clear waterholes and vast blue skies fill my soul. But it's also the big-hearted people and the richness of the community that make this place such fertile ground for stories."

As more local voices find their way onto bookshelves, Alice Springs is no longer just a setting for stories written elsewhere. It is becoming one of Australia's most distinctive literary centres — a place where stories are not only inspired by the desert but deeply rooted in it.

title: Why apartments with floor-to-ceiling windows are a 'trade-off' in Australia
text:
Llewellyn McGarry's apartment fitted the bill when she was looking to buy an energy-efficient, accessible dual-occupancy property for her and her mother.

The apartment in Canberra's south has sunset views of mountains to the west, and moving in over winter, Ms McGarry was surprised the floor-to-ceiling windows kept the apartment warm.

But both her apartment and her mother's are now sweltering through summer as indoor temperatures recently surpassed 40 degrees Celsius.

"It was unbelievable for me to think that it was 42 degrees here, which is what it was … at 5:50pm," Ms McGarry's mother Marie said.

"We didn't consider how hot it was going to get.

"It's a concrete building, double glazing, all these sorts of things that told me it was going to be okay [but] it wasn't. It was so hot."

Marie McGarry lives in the dual-occupancy home with her daughter. (ABC News: Lish Fejer)

Design challenge

As climate change brings hotter summers and more frequent heatwaves, experts have said it will be essential to better address the living conditions of apartment dwellers.

In the largest study of its kind in Australia, researchers are tracking the indoor temperatures, air quality, and window and air conditioning usage in 450 apartments across Sydney, Melbourne, and Queensland over two years to understand how apartment dwellers actually use energy and maintain comfort.

Over the recent heatwave, researchers, led by senior research scientist Pippa Soccio, surveyed participants to find out how comfortable they were in their apartments.

A CSIRO study found air movement was a problem in apartments deemed by occupants to be warm or very hot. (ABC News: Lish Fejer)

The results showed 25 per cent of participants felt warm or too hot in their apartments, with a lack of air movement the main problem.

"Very few of [the participants] have ceiling fans," Dr Soccio said.

"It's great to put air conditioning on to cool our homes down, but if we get a heatwave and a power outage and you can't use your air con, then can you open your home?

"Can you get air moving through, particularly when the cool change comes?"

Other causes of uncomfortably hot apartments included inadequate shading, ineffective air conditioning or people's choices not to use air conditioning.

Llewellyn McGarry says she has the air conditioning running all day in her Canberra apartment. (ABC News: Lish Fejer)

Window woes

Ms McGarry's experience isn't unique. Across Australia, residents in apartments are sweltering for months each year — despite meeting building standards

The hot indoor temperatures were particularly surprising as she had believed her double-glazed windows with a dark tint would have acted as a shield and maintained a comfortable temperature.

"I thought double glazing was about heating, cooling and noise, but as soon as the sun hits the surface, it actually feels hotter on the inside than it does on the outside," Ms McGarry said.

" You put your hand on it, it's so hot. It feels like it could burn. "

But building scientist Peter Lyons said, depending on the climate, glazing could be a trade-off between overheating in summer and free heating in winter.

"If you've got huge, glazed areas, particularly if they face west and are sheer facades with no shading, then those windows cop a huge amount of solar heat," Dr Lyons said.

"You might actually benefit from some of that solar gain in the winter, but the downside is they are going to be a liability in the summer."

Many apartments are designed with floor-to-ceiling windows to maximise light and views. (ABC News: Callum Flinn)

It is a design flaw repeated across Australian apartment buildings, which is part of the CSIRO's Apartment Energy Behaviour Study.

"There's a belief, I believe, that more glass gives us more access to daylight and daylight is preferable over artificial light," he said.

"[But] depending on your orientation, more glazing and daylight means more sunlight, which in turn means more radiant heat, which then obviously heats the apartment."

"I think it's great to use glazing, perhaps to frame a view rather than to necessarily capture the entire view," Dr Soccio added.

Limited solutions

Ms McGarry has installed internal blinds programmed to come down in the afternoon when the sun strikes.

In the bedrooms, she has added accordion-style blinds with reflective backing fitted into the window frame.

Marie McGarry says her apartment is unbearably hot in summer. (ABC News: Lish Fejer)

She said the additions had helped, but it was still too hot, and that even when the air conditioner was set to 19 degrees Celsius, the temperature rarely dropped below 24.

"It has improved in comparison to my mum's, but it's still quite hot in there. It was 30 degrees on Monday," she said.

Her energy bills are now costing up to $300 per month, which she said was higher than expected but also a medical necessity as she lives with a disability.

"As someone who can't regulate my temperature, anything above 24 [degrees Celsius] is actually incredibly uncomfortable, and I get quite ill," Ms McGarry said.

"We were after something long-term, like a forever home, that was going to be suitable to meet everything I needed and what mum needed … but we're just too hot."

Looking across at the new developments around them, Ms McGarry and her mother contemplate the prospect for future residents with floor-to-ceiling glass on all sides.

"These poor souls, they get the morning sun from this side of the building, and then they'll get the afternoon sun as well, so they'll get it all day and be cooked," Marie McGarry said.

title: 'Annoying' Marnus key to Heat's stunning BBL win over Hurricanes
text:
Brisbane Heat captain Usman Khawaja has credited gutsy field changes and the "annoyance of Marnus" for a miraculous Big Bash League win that has kept their finals hopes firmly alive.

The Hobart Hurricanes were in cruise control in pursuit of the Heat's 8-160 before they lost 6-32 to go down by three runs at Bellerive Oval on Wednesday night.

Defending champions Hobart would have sewn up top spot and a home qualifying final with a win but could now finish as low as third.

Meanwhile, the Heat jumped up to fourth and can secure a spot in the finals with victory over the Sydney Sixers at home on Sunday.

The Hurricanes were 2-124 in the 15th over when Beau Webster (51 off 43) holed out off Marnus Labuschagne, ending a 98-run stand with Ben McDermott that had the home side in the box seat.

"I knew if we could get a wicket that I could put pressure on a new batsman coming in," Khawaja said.

"Leg spinners always manage to get a wicket and Marnie was stirring up McDermott and Webster anyway.

"He's very annoying. We love him, but he's annoying to the opposition.

"McDermott and Marnus are really good friends and I kind of play emotion sometimes too … 'let's see if Marnus can get under their skin'. And he got us a wicket."

At that point, the Hurricanes needed a very gettable 37 from 35 balls with seven wickets in hand, but the wheels fell off in a collapse that included 4-6 across the final three overs.

Hobart needed just 11 runs off the final two overs after losing McDermott (59 off 36) and Matthew Wade (11 off 8).

Quick Xavier Bartlett got rid of Rehan Ahmed and Chris Jordan for ducks in a second-last over that only cost five runs with no boundaries, before Zaman Khan conceded just two off the final over and took the vital wicket of big-hitting Nikhil Chaudhary (16 off 17) as Hobart finished at 8-157.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Khawaja said he brought some of the fielders in closer for Bartlett with the goal of upping the pressure on the Hurricanes.

"You have to chance your arm a bit and when it comes off, it feels bloody good," he said.

Khawaja said the result was huge for the Heat's confidence — it was the first time they have notched back-to-back wins this season.

"The next game is big too but we've got control of our own destiny now, which will be a big boost for the boys," he said.

"We've given ourselves a chance."

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: In vet care deserts, an hour can be the difference between life and death
text:
In South Australia's north-east, where the Flinders Ranges meets the outback, more than 1,000 animals call Panaramitee Station home.

Caring for them on the remote station is fifth-generation farmer Lisa Crawford and her family.

The closest vet is nearly 200 kilometres away, or over 300 kilometres outside business hours.

It is a drive Ms Crawford has done many times, including one Saturday morning with an old border collie called Dodge.

Vets fear a lack of them in rural and regional areas could eventually result in a serious disease not being detected until it is too late. (ABC Rural: Isabella Kelly)

She drove more than two hours to the Clare Valley Veterinary Clinic, which is unable to provide 24/7 care.

After some testing and treatment, Dodge was discharged, but he collapsed again on the way home.

"At that stage we were almost three hours from Adelaide," Ms Crawford said.

"I got him down there, but they had to put him down."

She had driven 600km at this point, with only Dodge by her side.

Ms Crawford is one of 256,306 people without access to a vet in Australia, according to Bronwyn Orr, vet and former president of the Australian Veterinary Association.

The closest vet for Lisa Crawford's animals is nearly 200 kilometres away. It is another 100km for an emergency vet. (ABC Rural: Isabella Kelly)

Access to a vet was defined as being within an hour drive.

Sophie Browne, director and veterinarian at Clare Valley Veterinary Services, said many of her clients travel.

"We would probably see six to eight clients a day who have travelled anywhere from half an hour to an hour and a half," she said.

She said an hour could be the difference between life and death.

"We've had people call from Peterborough (116km away) or Orroroo (130km away) with a snakebite," Dr Browne said.

Dr Sophie Browne, director and veterinarian at Clare Valley Veterinary Services. (ABC Rural: Isabella Kelly)

" They get very, very close to us and have to turn around and go back because the dog has died in the car. "

The practice runs outreach days once a week, with staff travelling up to 200km.

Outside of those outreach days people like Ms Crawford can organise a visit but must pay for the travel.

"I've paid as much as $500 for travel, and then all the other stuff on top of that," Ms Crawford said.

"I'm lucky enough that I can afford that, not everyone can, but it's the animals that suffer in that scenario."

Dr Browne said it is not always viable for a vet clinic to be based in areas with smaller populations.

The work regional vets do with livestock includes reporting biosecurity risks. (ABC Rural: Isabella Kelly)

"We have to base ourselves somewhere where we have a consistent population and then try and radiate out as much as we can," she said.

Dr Browne said livestock and horses make up 25-30 per cent of business.

The work regional vets do with livestock includes reporting biosecurity risks, which Dr Orr said was "incredibly important".

"Every single day that disease occurs in the community and spreads without being detected costs hundreds of millions of dollars," she said.

"I do believe that eventually we'll get an incursion of a … serious disease and it will be picked up too late."

Is a shortage really to blame?

Workforce shortages have long been blamed for access issues, but Dr Orr said distribution was the problem.

"A shortage, in its most basic form implies that there's just not enough people being trained," Dr Orr said.

Dr Bronwyn Orr says vet distribution is the problem. (Supplied: Dr Bronwyn Orr)

"But I don't think that's actually true … We are producing more veterinarians than we ever have before.

" We have as many registered veterinarians in Australia as Canada, but Canada has 10 million more people. "

Dr Orr said the issue stemmed from veterinary care being "completely subject to the free market".

"A lot of GP clinics or pharmacies in rural and regional towns actually get a supplement from the government to be there … there is nothing like that in the veterinary world," she said.

"Either government steps in to subsidise veterinary practices in rural areas … or we accept that rural communities will start losing access to veterinary services on a more permanent basis."

Similar government intervention has occurred in several jurisdictions, including New Zealand and Canada.

Dr Orr said Australia has the same number of registered veterinarians as Canada, but Canada has 10 million more people. (ABC News: Alana Calvert)

A South Australian government spokesperson said the government was "aware of these proposals and acknowledges they are being discussed both nationally and within South Australia".

The spokesperson said incentives for regional vets and workforce attraction was "being examined" by the Joint Committee on the Mental Health and Wellbeing of Veterinarians in South Australia.

"Industry has an important role in supporting workforce sustainability, including through professional support, training opportunities, and initiatives that encourage veterinarians to consider regional practice," they said.

Workforce shortages have long been blamed for vet access issues. (ABC News: Ruby Littler)

The spokesperson said retention also had been "carefully considered" in drafting the Veterinary Services Act 2023.

"Once the act commences, it will introduce changes that are intended to support and encourage veterinarians to practise, or return to practising, in South Australia."

title: Satellite pics show lone tree at centre of probe into Alcoa's WA operations
text:
A single tree threatens to disrupt US mining giant Alcoa's expansion in Western Australia, with the company under investigation over an alleged breach of its state-imposed mining conditions.

Alcoa — which has mined bauxite in WA since the 1960s and employs about 4,000 people in the state — wants to expand further into the world's only jarrah forest, south-east of Perth.

The proposal is under review by the state's Environmental Protection Authority (EPA), which would typically require a project to stop while it's being assessed.

However, the WA government allowed Alcoa to keep mining during the assessment to "safeguard local jobs".

Alcoa's special exemption comes with conditions, including a requirement that mining must not occur within 10 metres of mature significant trees, which can provide nesting habitats for endangered black cockatoos.

The jarrah tree at the centre of an investigation into Alcoa's alleged mining breach. (Supplied)

The ABC can reveal the Department of Water and Environmental Regulation (DWER) is now investigating an alleged breach of that condition "as a priority".

Alcoa denies any wrongdoing, saying it takes its operating conditions "very seriously".

But if the alleged breach is proven, Alcoa could lose its exemption, making it illegal to continue mining while the EPA review is underway.

Single tree at centre of probe

Satellite imagery of part of Alcoa's Huntly Mine, 100 kilometres south of Perth, shows Alcoa's mining activities around a lone jarrah tree.

Satellite image of part of the Alcoa Huntly mine in September 2019. (Supplied: Nearmap)

Satellite image of part of the Alcoa Huntly mine in January 2023. (Supplied: Nearmap)

Over the past six years, the forest around the tree was cleared, and mined or turned into road.

Satellite image of part of the Alcoa Huntly mine in December 2023. (Supplied: Nearmap)

Some time after December 2023, a rock wall connected to the undisturbed island around the jarrah tree appears to have been knocked down.

Satellite image of part of the Alcoa Huntly mine in August 2025. (Supplied: Nearmap)

By August 2025, the tree appears to no longer have any leaves.

Politician trespasses to verify

WA Greens MLC Jess Beckerling said she was alerted to the tree by a concerned member of the public in December.

"We've unearthed some very compelling evidence that Alcoa appears to have breached its special exemption from WA environment laws," Ms Beckerling said.

WA Greens MLC Jess Beckerling. (ABC News: Cason Ho)

She trespassed through Alcoa's mining lease to try verifying the claims and take photos and videos of the scene.

Ms Beckerling measured the distance from the base of the tree to the northern edge of its island — about 9.1 metres — which is less than the required 10 metre radius.

Satellite imagery appears to corroborate Ms Beckerling's measurement but also shows a buffer of at least 10 metres at most other angles surrounding the tree.

"They've blasted through a rock wall ... and it appears that it's that disturbance which has caused this suspected breach," she said.

She referred the matter to the environmental regulation department, which has since confirmed it's investigating the alleged breach.

WA Greens MLC Jess Beckerling measured the diameter of the tree, and the distance to an edge of the unmined land. (Supplied: Jess Beckerling)

The department would not provide a timeline for how long the investigation could take.

"It would not be appropriate to make further comment while the investigation is ongoing," a DWER spokesperson said.

In a statement, Alcoa said it had applied a 10-metre buffer around the tree since it was identified in 2014 pre-mining surveys.

"Mining took place at various times until March 2024. None of this activity breached the applicable 10m buffer zone," a spokesperson said.

"The tree was not identified as a black cockatoo nesting tree.

"Alcoa takes the conditions governing our operations very seriously and we consider that we are operating in accordance with the section 6 exemption order."

Defending trespass

Asked about whether it was appropriate for an elected member of parliament to knowingly break the law by trespassing, Ms Beckerling said she was motivated by a sense of public duty.

Jess Beckerling defended her trespassing onto Alcoa property. (ABC News: Cason Ho)

"I have a responsibility to do what I can to protect the Northern Jarrah Forrest from this strip mining," she said.

"I was very cautious in the way that I went about finding this information. I waited until the end of a non-work day. I was certain that there was no mining activity occurring."

Ms Beckerling said she was not suggesting anyone should follow her example.

"It's not my place to encourage or discourage other people to do what they think is right," she said.

Unique arrangements

Alcoa is exempt from most of the state's environmental laws and is instead governed under state agreements, which allow it to mine in WA's state forest.

A government committee reviews the company's five-year mining plans which are implemented on a rolling basis to allow continuity in Alcoa's operations.

Alcoa's mining footprint between 1984 and 2022. (Supplied: Google Earth)

However, environmental protection laws do not allow a project to be implemented while it's being assessed by the EPA.

To prevent disruption, the WA government declared an exemption order allowing Alcoa's operations to continue despite the EPA assessment.

WA Premier Roger Cook said at the time the exemption was necessary to protect thousands of jobs, which would be put at risk if Alcoa needed to stop its operations.

Alcoa has mined in WA for bauxite, used to create aluminium, since the 1960s and employs about 4,000 people. (Supplied: Landgate)

The exemption order limits where and how much the company can mine, including the requirement to avoid mining near significant trees.

If those conditions are found to not have been met, the exemption ceases to have effect, meaning it would become illegal for Alcoa to continue any of its operations which are being assessed by the EPA.

In a statement, Alcoa reiterated its commitment to "working responsibly to balance environmental and social considerations".

"We continue to enhance protections for environmentally significant areas, including proposing to apply a 30m buffer around known and suitable black cockatoo nesting trees, significant trees, and night-time roosting trees," a spokesperson said.

"We continue to work with regulators, third-party consultants, and researchers to maintain our commitment to continuously improving our approaches."

title: Costly Starlink units adding to financial pressure on volunteer fire brigades
text:
Volunteer fire brigades and regional communities across Western Australia's heartland are being forced to self-fund expensive satellite equipment, as mobile drop-outs continue to impact bushfire fights.

Widespread mobile blackouts during bushfires across the Wheatbelt in December were the latest example of firefighters left unable to communicate after mobile towers lost power.

But in the Shire of Victoria Plains, around 160 kilometres north-east of Perth, a recent decision to fit Starlink units to five of the local fire brigade's trucks left communications intact.

Firefighters battled a five-day blaze which went through the Mogumber Mission in December. (Supplied: Department of Fire and Emergency Services)

The units allow for the vehicles to access high-speed internet through the Elon Musk-run company's low-earth orbit satellites, at the cost of $20,000 for the installation.

Chief Bushfire Control officer Gavin Halligan said the units were the only way responders were able to communicate outside the fire ground during the five-day firefight near Mogumber.

"We managed to get choppers in, speak to DFES ... and keeping logistics up like water tanks on certain roads," he said.

Starlink units have been fitted to several volunteer bushfire brigade vehicles. (Supplied: Shane Hart)

The units' effectiveness has seen more country councils following suit, with the neighbouring Shire of Dandaragan planning to purchase two or three more units.

Further north, the Shire of Coorow is installing 10 Starlink units on its fire response vehicles, with help from a local gas company to meet the $30,000 price tag.

Coorow Shire president Guy Sims said the region's history of poor mobile communications made the move unsurprising.

Coorow shire president Guy Sims says the new technology is essential. (Supplied: Shire of Coorow)

"Starlink is still a relatively new technology, but it's a technology that's proving itself," he said.

"I think it's going to become pretty well essential from now on."

Increasing reliance

The move continues a national trend of public and private consumers relying on Starlink for their internet and mobile services.

They include WA's Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES) which said its cache of Starlink units are "dispatched as required", including to the recent Midwest fires.

The increasing reliance on Starlink in Australia has drawn criticism about its unpredictable owner, Elon Musk. (Reuters: Mike Blake)

At least 375,000 Starlink units were connected across the country last year, according to federal government data.

The increasing reliance on the service within Australia has drawn concern about its potential to make the country more vulnerable to the whims of its unpredictable owner.

But Dandaragan Shire president Tony O'Gorman said reliable communications were the paramount concern.

"I think we all have concerns about Elon Musk," he said.

"The fact of the matter is it's the only technology that is available at the moment, and I will put the safety of our firefighters ahead of any idealisms that people have."

Shire of Dandaragan shire president Tony O'Gorman says Starlink provides a reliable extra line of communication. (ABC News: Briana Shepherd)

In Coorow, Community Emergency Services manager Mick Antony said volunteers were increasingly dipping into their own pockets to install the units.

"Communication is the highest priority, as well as the actual fire-fighting," he said.

" Everyone needs to be alerted. We need to get that information out. "

Starlink directly competes with the Australian government's NBN satellite option.

Starlink, which is owned by controversial billionaire Elon Musk, has become increasingly popular in regional communities. (ABC Midwest & Wheatbelt: Chloe Henville)

However, the "Sky Muster" product will soon be replaced with a new Amazon satellite product, following a partnership between the tech giant and NBN.

An Albanese government spokesperson said it supported a competitive communications market and was investing to make mobile connectivity more resilient across regional Australia.

Funding shortfalls

With the state government not currently funding brigades' Starlink purchases, local governments are having to find other funding methods.

In a recent state budget submission, the WA Local Government Association said volunteer bushfire brigades across the state were short $42 million in unmet grant requests.

Bushfire Volunteers Association executive officer Shane Hart says volunteer brigades need more funding for appropriate vehicles and equipment. (Supplied: Shane Hart)

However, Bushfire Volunteers Association executive officer Shane Hart said it was a symptom of a broader funding problem.

"Many local governments still don't have the sustainable funding to purchase or maintain the equipment brigades need," he said.

" Eligibility is not the main problem, the funding model is. "

A state government spokesperson did not address questions about funding, but pointed to $69 million granted to local governments for bushfire mitigation since 2017.

title: Scott Robertson steps down as All Blacks coach. Could Joe Schmidt replace him?
text:
Scott Robertson has left his role as New Zealand head coach 20 months before their World Cup opener against Australia, a move that could open up an opportunity for Wallabies coach Joe Schmidt.

The Irish Independent first reported player power was a factor in the former Crusaders coach not taking charge of New Zealand in 2026 after he received damning feedback in an end of season review. New Zealand Rugby confirmed the coach’s immediate departure on Thursday.

“Scott Robertson has departed his role as head coach of the All Blacks following the completion of the 2025 end of season review,” a statement released by New Zealand Rugby said.

“A process will commence immediately to recruit a new head coach.”

title: Commuters to cop eight weekend closures of Sydney’s metro line to finish final stage
text:
Commuters face about another eight weekend closures of parts or all of Sydney’s M1 metro line to allow for testing of trains and other work on the final section of the rail project between Sydenham and Bankstown before it opens.

As high-speed testing along the final stage ramps up, a metro train travelled the entire length of the 66-kilometre M1 line from Tallawong to Bankstown via the city, stopping at all 31 stations. The train reached speeds of 100km/h on the final section between Sydenham and Bankstown.

Southwest Metro project director Alia Karaman said about eight weekend shutdowns of parts or all of the existing M1 line would be required to complete the final stage.

A metro train passes Transport Minister John Graham, left, and other ministers and officials on a platform at Wiley Park station on Thursday. Credit: Kate Geraghty

“If we don’t shut down, then it means we’re not able to complete a critical part of the work,” she said. “The number [of shutdowns] will vary depending on the functionality that’s required, the events and the weekend that we are targeting.”

title: Adelaide Festival apologises for debacle, invites ousted writer to 2027 event
text:
The Adelaide Festival has apologised unreservedly to Palestinian-Australian writer Dr Randa Abdel-Fattah after removing her from the 2026 Adelaide Writers’ Week program and invited her to feature in the line-up next year.

The about-turn comes after days of turmoil in South Australia, with the cancellation on Tuesday of Adelaide Writers’ Week, and the resignation of AWW director Louise Adler after 180 authors quit the line-up over the Adelaide Festival board’s decision to remove Abdel-Fattah from the literary event’s program.

Randa Abdel-Fattah. Credit: AAPIMAGE

Last Thursday, the festival board announced that while it was not suggesting “in any way” that Abdel-Fattah or her writing had any connection with the Bondi attack, given her past statements, “it would not be culturally sensitive to continue to program her at this unprecedented time so soon after Bondi”. Adelaide Festival chair Tracey Whiting resigned on Sunday and new board members were appointed this week.

The festival’s apology comes a day after former Adelaide Festival board member Tony Berg accused Adler of hypocrisy over free speech, saying she threatened to resign from her role in 2024 unless the board cancelled an invitation to a Jewish New York Times journalist Thomas Friedman. On Thursday, Friedman told this masthead that he did not withdraw from the 2024 event of his own volition but was uninvited by organisers, who told him “the timing” would not work.
